newsitem.title: USA: N. Carolina bill would eliminate housing bond cap.
newsitem.headline: N. Carolina bill would eliminate housing bond cap.

text.p: A bill pending in the North Carolina General Assembly would eliminate the $1.5 billion lifetime cap on bond issuance by the state's Housing Finance Agency.

The agency would still be barred from having more than $1.5 billion of bonds outstanding at any one time, but would have no lifetime limit, said Martha Harris, the legislative attorney who drafted the bill.
The proposal, SB289, was sponsored by Sen. David Hoyle, D-Dallas, at the request of the housing agency.

The agency has issued $1.3 billion of bonds since its inception in the late 1970s and has $865 milion currently outstanding. It plans to issue $175 million of single-family housing bonds and $25 million of multi-family housing bonds next year, said agency Finance Director Lyn Casey.
"We're going to have to raise that cap or stop issuing bonds," Casey said.
She said the bill was not considered controversial and was expected to pass.

Most North Carolina agencies have no lifetime cap on debt issuance. The limit on housing bonds was set when the agency was created, at a time when "housing agencies were new and no one really new how they would work," Casey said.
